text: Over the past [redacted]weeks, national surveillance summaries across Africa have shown a clear shift in respiratory and syndromic activity. Following a period of declining reports, a recent upward trend has been observed, with elevated momentum noted in the most recent data. This increasing activity is not uniform, with regional heterogeneity evident between West, East, and Southern Africa, while co-circulation of other respiratory pathogens has been mentioned in some sentinel site reports. The observed rise coincides with typical seasonal patterns and increased mobility. Public health guidance remains in effect, though some areas note reporting cadence and data completeness have been affected by known logistical lags and access constraints, which can influence the overall picture.

Over the past [redacted]weeks, national surveillance summaries and sentinel site reports from across Africa have indicated a period of steady respiratory and syndromic activity. This stable baseline has recently given way to a rising trend, with elevated momentum now being observed in the near term. Regional heterogeneity is evident, with variations in reporting cadence and data completeness noted between West, East, Central, Southern, and North Africa. This upward shift coincides with typical seasonal factors, including rainy periods in some regions and increased mobility. Co-circulation of other respiratory pathogens has been mentioned in some reports, while public health guidance and vaccination efforts have remained in effect. Access constraints, including logistical challenges and extreme weather, have been noted as factors influencing the observed data in certain areas.

Over the past [redacted]weeks, national surveillance summaries across Africa have shown a rising trajectory in syndromic respiratory activity. This upward trend has recently intensified, with elevated momentum observed in many reporting regions, although the picture remains heterogeneous with varying levels of data completeness. The co-circulation of multiple respiratory pathogens has been noted in several areas, with seasonal factors and population mobility likely contributing to the increased case burden. Concurrently, public health guidance and vaccination efforts have been actively maintained. Despite the recent increasing activity, the latest data indicates the beginning of a declining trend, suggesting a potential shift in the outbreak's trajectory as reporting continues.

This upward momentum has recently shifted to a broadly unchanged state, with the overall level of activity now appearing stable. Regional heterogeneity has been observed, with variations noted between West, East, Central, Southern, and North Africa, influenced by seasonal factors and population mobility. Co-circulation of other respiratory pathogens has been reported in some areas. Public health guidance and vaccination efforts have remained in effect. While reporting cadence and data completeness vary, and some access constraints have been noted, the current assessment based on available data indicates a steady situation with little change in the near-term [redacted].
